Value.Value: Reason Water level has been low for a while and the sand is shifting between the foundation. Solution Do your research and hire someone to investigate the soil. Afterwards, replenish the soil with water by building a dam under the surface near the affected buildings.
Ok!

Reason Erosion can occur in this type of soil, this causes the foundation to collapse underneath the weight of the house. Solution Research the underlying soil and make sure the foundation is still okay, if it's not. hire a company that will stabilize the foundation.
Ok!

Reason Clay shrinks during the summer and expands during the winter due to moisture. Trees might also affect this phenomena. Solution Do your research and hire someone to investigate the soil. Afterwards, replenish the soil with water by building a dam under the surface near the affected buildings.
Ok!

Reason This kind of soil is also known as soft soil and is now more often used to farm on, but older houses have the chance of having peat under their houses. Peat is very unstable and foundations often get destabilized on this kind of soil because it holds a lot of moisture all throughout the year. Solution Using lime and cement this is you can stabilize peat up till a certain degree. Of course, first always consult a professional before you do anything.
Ok!

Reason The soil is dried out hence exposing the poles to oxygen creating wood rot. Solution After doing the research on your soil and foundation, contact a professional and let them place extra support or come with a different solution.
Ok!
Reason The building has become to heavy for this type of foundation. Solution Support the foundation by adding extra poles near the issue area.
Ok!

Reason Corrosion of reinforcing steel and other embedded metals is the leading cause of deterioration in concrete. When steel corrodes, the resulting rust occupies a greater volume than the steel. This expan- sion creates tensile stresses in the concrete, which can eventually cause cracking, delamination, and spalling. Solution If it is only on the surface, you can easily maintain it with water and extra cement to fill the cracks and gaps. If the problem is deeper, the foundation will need to be reinforced, often done with steel pins(screw pins).
Ok!

Reason The plate shifted and is sinking often to one side this will often cause the house to tilt to a side. Solution Lift the plate on the affected side with steel pins to level and evenly distribute the weight over the floating plate again.
Ok!
Reason The foundation is shifting because of weather circumstances affecting the soil. Solution Ask the previous owners if they had this problem and then go to the town hall to research your house.
Ok!
Reason The foundation is shifting because of age and exposure to the weather. Solution Research the foundation and let an expert come to figure out what the best course of action is.
Ok!
Reason The annex is not built on a good foundation so it is sinking in the soil because of its weight. Solution Add more support to strengthen the foundation and then repair the visible damage.
Ok!

Reason The surrounding area is sinking around the building,creating a big height difference. Solution This is an issue that only the townhall can solve by actually opening up the streets and applying more soil.
Ok!
Reason The weight of the building has become too heavy for the soil and foundation. Solution Add extra support to the foundation.
Ok!
